member.name: T:Symbology.CustomSymbolStyleItem
member.summary: Represents a custom symbol style item.
member.remarks: Procedural symbol items do not have a preview image. So a custom png is used to display these symbol types in the dockpane

member.name: M:Symbology.MeshSymbology.CreateMeshSymbolAsync
member.summary: Create a mesh symbol that can be applied to a multi-patch feature layer.
member.remarks: A mesh symbol is a CIMMeshSymbol object. Define an array of CIMSymbolLayers which contains a CIMMaterialSymbol layer with the specified properties such as Color, etc. Assign this array of CIMSymbolLayers to the CIMMeshSymbol. ![MeshSymbolOrange](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/mesh-material-orange.png)

member.name: F:Symbology.MeshSymbology._rulePkgPath
member.summary: Creates Mesh procedural symbol with various textures. ![MeshProceduralTexture](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/mesh-procedural-texture.png)
member.remarks: Note: The rule package used in this method can be obtained from the Sample Data included in the arcgis-pro-sdk-community-samples repository.

member.name: M:Symbology.MyLineSymbology.CreateMyMarkerLineSymbolAsync
member.summary:
Create a line symbol with the markers placed at a 45 degree angle.
![LineSymbolAngleMarker](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/line-marker-angle.png)

member.name: M:Symbology.MyLineSymbology.CreateLineDashTwoMarkersAync
member.summary: Create a line symbol with a dash and two markers.
member.remarks: This line symbol comprises three symbol layers listed below: 1. A solid stroke that has dashes. 1. A circle marker. 1. A square marker. ![LineSymbolTwoMarkers](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/line-dash-two-markers.png)

member.name: M:Symbology.MyLineSymbology.CreateLineDashTwoMarkers2Async
member.summary:
Create a line symbol with a dash and two markers.
In this pattern of creating this symbol, a [CIMVectorMarker](http://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/sdk/api-reference/#topic6176.html) object is created as a new [CIMSymbolLayer](http://prodev.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/sdk/api-reference/#topic5503.html). The circle and square markers created by [ContructMarker](http://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/sdk/api-reference/#topic12350.html) method is then assigned to the [MarkerGraphics](http://prodev.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/sdk/api-reference/#topic6188.html) property of the CIMVectorMarker. When using this method, the CIMVectorMarker's [Frame](http://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/sdk/api-reference/#topic6187.html) property needs to be set to the [CIMMarker](http://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/sdk/api-reference/#topic3264.html) object's Frame. Similarly, the CIMVectorMarker's [Size](http://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/sdk/api-reference/#topic3284.html) property needs to be set to the CIMMarker object's size.
member.remarks: This line symbol comprises three symbol layers listed below: 1. A solid stroke that has dashes. 1. A circle marker. 1. A square marker. ![LineSymbolTwoMarkers](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/line-dash-two-markers.png)

member.name: T:Symbology.Module1
member.summary: This sample creates custom point, line and polygon symbol items that you can use to render feature layers. These symbol items are stored in a personal style file in your project that you can re-use.
member.remarks: 1. In Visual Studio click the Build menu. Then select Build Solution. 1. Click Start button to open ArcGIS Pro. 1. ArcGIS Pro will open. 1. Open any project file. 1. In Add-in tab, click the "Show Symbology pane" button. 1. In the Symbology pane, you can see the custom Point, Line and Polygon symbols available in this sample. Select each of these items in the combo box to see the available symbols. ![UI](Screenshots/SymbologyPane.png) 1. In the project, access the Style project items available in the current project using the Catalog Pane. 1. Click the MyCustomSymbols style project item. This is a personal style file created by the sample. It comprises all the symbols you saw in the Symbology pane. ![UI](Screenshots/CustomStyleProjectItem.png) 1. You can now use these custom symbols to render any feature layer.

member.name: P:Symbology.Module1.Current
member.summary: Retrieve the singleton instance to this module here.

member.name: M:Symbology.Module1.CanUnload
member.summary: Called by Framework when ArcGIS Pro is closing
member.returns: False to prevent Pro from closing, otherwise True

member.summary: Creates a point symbol with custom fill and outline ![PointSymbolMarker](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/point-fill-outline.png)

member.summary:
Create a polygon symbol with a cross hatch fill.
![PolygonSymbolCrossHatch](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/polygon-crosshatch.png)

member.name: M:Symbology.MyPolygonSymbology.CreateDiagonalCrossPolygonAsync
member.summary:
Create a polygon symbol with a diagonal cross hatch fill.
![PolygonSymbolDiagonalCrossHatch](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/polygon-diagonal-crosshatch.png)

member.name: M:Symbology.MyPolygonSymbology.CreateDashDotFillAsync
member.summary:
Create a polygon symbol with a dash dot fill.
![PolygonSymbolDashDot](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/polygon-dash-dot.png)

member.name: M:Symbology.MyPolygonSymbology.CreateGradientFillAsync
member.summary:
Create a polygon symbol with a gradient color fill.
![PolygonSymbolGradientColor](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/polygon-gradient-color.png)
member.remarks: 1. Create a solid colored stroke with 50% transparency 1. Create a fill using gradient colors red through green 1. Apply both the stroke and fill as a symbol layer array to the new PolygonSymbol

member.name: F:Symbology.MyPolygonSymbology._rulePkgPath
member.summary: Create a procedural symbol that can be applied to a polygon building footprint layer ![ProceduralSymbol](http://Esri.github.io/arcgis-pro-sdk/images/Symbology/polygon-procedural.png)
member.remarks: Note: The rule package used in this method can be obtained from the Sample Data included in the arcgis-pro-sdk-community-samples repository.
